--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Harris" <benkei@b...>
wrote:
> Milt,
>
> You're right, now that I look at it, it should probably sell for
$50, but I
> opened my mouth, and my single copy is now sold.
>
> I was probably thinking of:
>
> Dunn, Roger [Editor]. Token Taikai. San Francisco: Northern
California
> Japanese Sword Club, 1976. First edition. Transcripts of 11 lectures
> presented at the Token Taikai in San Francisco in 1976, plus three
other
> papers not presented but included to augment the lecture topics.
Includes
> papers on armor, swords, sword fittings and history by noted
authors John
> Yumoto, Dr. Benjamin H. Hazard, Thomas Buttweiler, Dean Hartley, K.
K.
> Chappelear, Robert Haynes and K. Torigoye.
> [This copy noted in red ink on the Introduction page as Book
Number "27."
> Unknown how many copies were printed.] Very Good in Wraps
>
> Which I do have two copies of @ $35, not $25. It's a bitch getting
older ...

> Craig
>

Craig !!

you subscribe to the first law of the Faranghi ?
It says.......... " there is no shame in being expensive "
the second law says........ " the stupidity of other species is not
the fault of the Faranghis "

that 11 lectures book in hard cover for 35 beans ? It's an excellent
book even at twice your asking price.

By the way, I have a copy of the " meibutsu " 79 catalog with fold
out oshigata for sale at 50 + 5.00 shipping. As you can deduce, i
do follow the laws of the Faranghis when selling ......... =)

milt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Crass Commercial Message, books and sword for sale.
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, You re right, now that I look at it, it should probably sell for $50, but I opened my mouth, and my single copy is now sold. I was probably thinking of:
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

You're right, now that I look at it, it should probably sell for $50, but I
opened my mouth, and my single copy is now sold.

I was probably thinking of:

Dunn, Roger [Editor]. Token Taikai. San Francisco: Northern California
Japanese Sword Club, 1976. First edition. Transcripts of 11 lectures
presented at the Token Taikai in San Francisco in 1976, plus three other
papers not presented but included to augment the lecture topics. Includes
papers on armor, swords, sword fittings and history by noted authors John
Yumoto, Dr. Benjamin H. Hazard, Thomas Buttweiler, Dean Hartley, K. K.
Chappelear, Robert Haynes and K. Torigoye.
[This copy noted in red ink on the Introduction page as Book Number "27."
Unknown how many copies were printed.] Very Good in Wraps

Which I do have two copies of @ $35, not $25. It's a bitch getting older ...

Craig

only 25 beans for that great " catalog " with fold out oshigata ?

Milt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Crass Commercial Message, books and sword for sale.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Craig, The prices reflect the fact that most books are in near mint condition, I am extremely picky when it comes to my books, and can t stand damaged ones
messages.messageBody:
Hi Craig,

The prices reflect the fact that most books are in near mint condition,
I am extremely picky when it comes to my books, and can't stand damaged
ones and prefer to pay a premium for perfect examples. In practice this
is not always possible but I do try...... However I think you will find
that most of these prices are still lower than what is common on the
net. Try Satcho, Jinsoo or Mr. Weissberg for example. That being said
offers are always considered, I am pretty difficult to insult as far as
that goes.

I can let the book you want go for $85 including wordwide shipping. That
works out at the same as the ebay one if you add on the shipping to
that. And ofcourse since I am in the Netherlands your weak dollar is not
helping much either :-)

- Matt



Z Recruiting Services
"Zurich Toren" Muzenstraat 89
2511 WB Den Haag
T: +31 70 4262273
F: +31 70 4262111
W: zrecruiting.com
E: info@...
Kijk ook op monsterboard.nl, jobbingmall.nl en
nationalevacaturebank.nl voor actuele vacatures!


-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Craig Harris [mailto:benkei@...]
Verzonden: donderdag 1 januari 2004 22:35
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: RE: [nihontostudy] Crass Commercial Message, books and sword
for sale.


Matt,

I would want your #11, I've been looking for it for some time, but your
prices! Enough to make a predatory bookseller blush! Even the last copy
Mike
Y. (historian333) sold on eBay only went for $70 or so. (I missed seeing
the
auction until it was over.)

As someone who, as of today, officially will be making my living selling
books, I am comforted by your prices - I have many of the same titles -
and
do hope you get them, it bodes well for my business if you do.

Let me know if there is something we can work out, even a trade for
something you are looking for ...

Craig L. Harris - Rare Books
Bridge of Dreams, LLC

Matt,

I would want your #11, I've been looking for it for some time, but your

As someone who, as of today, officially will be making my living selling

Let me know if there is something we can work out, even a trade for
something you are looking for ...

Craig L. Harris - Rare Books
Bridge of Dreams, LLC


-----Original Message-----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle [mailto:matthewhoyle@...] On Behalf Of
matthewhoyle@...
Sent: Thursday, January 01, 2004 2:06 PM
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...; nihonto@yahoogroups.com;
nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Crass Commercial Message, books and sword for sale.


Gang, I have decided to start the new year off by selling part of my
treasured book collection, as well as the first sword I ever bought. Take a
moment to look this post over, some of these items are pretty hard to come
by these days. Free shipping to list members within Europe, 50% off shipping
to all others. Extensive descriptions and pix available on request.

For Sale Books:

1. Japanese Swords & Sword Furniture in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston by
Morihiro Ogawa 1987. Hardback. This is a big heavy book that is quite rare
now. Over 400 items listed in 423 pages. Lots of juyo quality stuff, making
this a super reference book. Very good copy with very good dustjacket. Some
slight fading to the spine (dj) and some very small bumps only, otherwise
perfect. Comes with separate glossery in mint condition. Asking $450

2. The Armour book in Honcho-Gunkiko by Arai Hakuseki 1964. Hardback. Rare
reference book. Very good condition, with only one very small tear to the
back of the dustjacket and priceclipped. Comes with protective brodart cover
for the dj. Asking $200

3. The Hartman Collection of Japanese metalwork by Christie's, Mason and
Woods Ltd 1976. Published as a hardback with no dustjacket this book is in
very good condition also. Only slight fading to the spine, otherwise
perfect. Comes with original errata and list of estimates (loose).
Unfortunately no list of prices realised. A definate must have for any
serious tsuba or kodogu collector, the collection of tsuba within is simply
stunning. Asking $150

4. Masterpieces of the R. B. Caldwell collection of Japanese Sword Fittings
by Patrick Syz 1994. Hardback. One very tiny crease to the top of the
dustjacket (hardly noticeable), otherwise absolutely mint. Comes with
protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking $200

5. The Arts of the Japanese Sword by B.W. Robinson. First edition, 1961.
Hardback. The book that every novice sword collector should have in his /
her collection. Very good condition, but no dustjacket. Some small scratches
to the boards and minor bumping in the corners. Asking $125

6. Nippon-To The Japanese Sword by Inami Hakusui 1948. Hardback. An absolute
Classic, this was the first English reference book written by a noted
Japanese expert. In super condition, this book is a treasure to behold. One
small tear to the dustjacket next to the spine only. No fading, no creases,
nothing. The book looks like it was published yesterday ! Interesting little
vintage pamphlet from the Japan Sword Co selling kitchen knives inside.
Comes with protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking $250

7. Early Japanese Sword Guards; Sukashi Tsuba, by Masayuki Sasano 1972.
Hardback. Classic reference book on sukashi tsuba this usually retails in
the $225 - 300 range depending on condition. Hoever this example is ex
libris and has the usual library stamps inside. When it was in the library
the dustjacket was stuck to the inside of the book(!). This has since been
remedied and the dustjacket is now loose and comes in a protective brodart
cover but you can still see where it used to be stuck on. Otherwise in good
- very good condition. Asking $175

8. The Carlo Monzino Collection of Japanese Sword Fittings and Swords by
Sotheby's 1996. Wonderful hardback auction catalog in mint condition. 122
pages of outstanding pieces. Asking $60

9. Japanese Master Swordsmiths: The Gassan Tradition by The Museum of Fine
Arts, Boston 1989. Softcover in very fine condition. Must have reference for
any Gassan enthousiast. Asking $75

10. Tosogu, Treasure of the Samurai by Sarzi-Amade Limited, 1991. Scarce
catalog full of tsuba and other sword fittings, very lavishly illustrated.
In extremely good condition and very hard to come by. This is recommended
for any kodogu lover. Comes with protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking
$125

11. Tsuba II: Returned Tsuba from Europe, by Inami Tomihiko. Hardback. This
is the second of a set of two describing various tsuba that were returned
from Germany and Europe to Japan. Both are very hard to find. An interesting
book with 200 tsuba illustrated in this volume, most in b/w but also quite a
few in color. Be warned this book is in Japanese though! Extremely good
condition all round. Comes with protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking
$100

12. Illustrated catalogues of Tokyo National Museum Sword guard(s) by Tokyo
National Museum, 1979. Hardback. Another scarce / rare book illustrating 542
tsubas in the Tokyo National Museum. Black and white pictures
unfortunately, but still a must have reference for any serious tsuba
collector. I saw one copy in tatty condition sell on ebay last year for
something like $300 (!). This copy is in very good to fine condition. Comes
with protective brodart cover for the dj. Asking $175


Right and now on to the sword that I have for sale. This Nambokucho (14th
century) sword was purchased last year from Aoi Arts in Japan. It comes with
fairly recent NBTHK Tokubetsu Hozon papers, a professional oshigata done at
Aoi Arts and their own menu shaped certificate describing the sword and
stating that it was then valued at 1,2 million yen. The sword is in a
shirasaya, no koshirae and is in excellent polish. I was toying with the
idea of submitting it to Juyo Shinsa, but have so far not got round to it. I
don't know if it would stand a chance of going Juyo, but I think that it
should be submitted if only just for the experience which would be very
educational in my opinion. It is attributed to the Nakajima Rai school which
seems to be pretty darn rare. At least this is the only one I have ever
seen. Below is the info exactly as on the Aoi Arts certificate.

'We certify the following Katana is genuine. Detail, Katana: the NBTHK
Tokubetsu-hozon token.
Signature: Unsigned, attributed to Nakajima-Rai. The blade is polished, in a
shirasaya. Blade length: 62.7 cm or 24.69 inches.
Sori: 1.0 cm or 0.39 inch.
Width at the hamachi: 2.98cm or 1.17 inches.
Width at the yokote: 2.11 cm or 0.83 inch.
Thickness at the hamachi: 0.74 cm or 0.29 inch.
Era: Nambokucho-period. 14th century.

Shape: A shinogi-zukuri katana. Broadish blade has plenty thickness and the
point is O-kissaki.
Jitetsu: Small mokume is combined with small itame-hada. Fine jitetsu bears
delicate jinie.
Hamon: Nie-deki. Naka-suguha hamon goes with ashi, yo, kinsuji and
sunagashi.
Boshi: Niju-ba turns back roundly on the front.

A glance at this sword shows that clearly Rai School tradition. Acceptable
o-hada appears about six inches above the hamachi. Superb jitetsu and
sensitive works on the ha are the point of appreciation. 1,200,000 Yen.'

I still have the original Aoi Arts pictures that can be sent on request.
Asking $12,500.



Thanks for taking the time to read all this and let me know if I can be of
any further help or if any of you want pix or more detailed descriptions.
matthew@...

- Matthew.



Z Recruiting Services
"Zurich Toren" Muzenstraat 89
2511 WB Den Haag
T: +31 70 4262273
F: +31 70 4262111
W: zrecruiting.com
E: info@...
Kijk ook op monsterboard.nl, jobbingmall.nl en
nationalevacaturebank.nl voor actuele vacatures!
